docs.snippet: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage....
docs.lead_paragraph: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.
docs.abstract: Sam Borden On Soccer column notes that the United States national soccer team does not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as other World Cup squads, putting them at strategic disadvantage; argues that, for better or worse, playacting is part of the game and has already been a decisive factor in several World Cup matches.

headline.main: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Soccer Falls Short

docs.snippet: Tony Gwynn could handle a bat like few other major leaguers, whether it was driving the ball through the "5.5 hole" between third base and shortstop or hitting a home run off the facade in Yankee Stadium in the World Series....
